CatDescriptText: Frank Alexander, postal clerk, Fifth Ward and Edward Carter, laborer, Third Ward, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, October 28, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., should come to Pittsburgh and take over the pastorate of a church, or should he remain in the South and continue his crusade?" Mr. Alexander's answer reads: "In my opinion, I think he's doing so much good in the South that the South would be lost without him.  It would be just like taking a general from a field of battle."  Mr. Carter's answer reads: "He should stay in the South, because he would do more there than here.  The situation is pretty much in hand here, but he's needed so much in the South."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Frank Alexander wearing trench coat and hat; Portrait of Edward Carter wearing light colored jacket with knitted checkered trim and hat
